Rationale  Sustainable growth of the agriculture sector is a prerequisite for 
economic growth and poverty reduction in Viet Nam. Despite the 
progress made in agricultural production and export growth, and 
in liberalizing commodity, land, and credit markets in recent years, 
rural  poverty  remains  high  and  the  level  of  private  sector 
investment  remains low. Growth in the past was the result of 
(i) reliance on higher input use (labor, land, fertilizer, tractors, and 
irrigation);  (ii)  policy  reforms  in  land,  markets,  and  trade;  and 
(iii) high public investment, mainly in irrigation and roads. This 
strategy will not be able to sustain growth in the future because 
(i) the potential for expanding the rural labor force and land under 
cultivation  is  limited;  (ii)  new  investment  in  irrigation  exhibits 
decreasing marginal returns as the stock of irrigation capital is 
already  very  high  and  requires  increased  operation  and 
maintenance rather than new expansion; and (iii) revenue from 
rice  export  is  declining.  Viet  Nam  is  already  experiencing 
overproduction  of  rice,  coffee,  and  other  commodities  and 
declining export revenues from unprocessed commodities. As a 
result, the Government is paying high storage costs for these 
unsold goods.  
 
Policy  makers  in  the  Government  are  interested  in  sustaining 
growth, employment, and exports in agriculture so as to reduce 
rural  poverty  and  in  effecting  policy  reforms  for  commercial 
agriculture,  livestock,  water  resources,  and  forestry.  Policy 
reforms  in  the  development  and  use  of  technologies  through 
research and extension and improved access to credit by small- 
and  medium-sized  enterprises  (SMEs)  are  expected  to 
(i) increase  factor  productivity;  (ii)  improve  yields;  (iii)  foster 
diversification  into  available  markets  for  higher  value  crops; 
(iv) improve the quality of products such as rice, coffee, livestock 
products,  fruits  and  vegetables  that  respond  to  and  meet  the 
requirements  of  specific,  well-targeted  domestic  and  export 
markets; (v) increase value-added production; and (vi) expand 
rural industries and services. With increased understanding of and 
responsiveness  to  different  markets,  competitiveness  in  export 
markets is expected to improve. In turn, this is expected to have 
beneficial impacts on rural poverty by increasing employment and 
reducing indebtedness and sales of landholdings.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on the proposed loans 
to the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Agriculture Sector Development Program.  
II.  THE SECTOR: PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Sector Description and Performance 
2.  By most measures of performance, Viet Nam has experienced successful economic 
growth and poverty reduction over the last 15 years since economic reform or doi moi was 
introduced in 1986. During the 1990s, gross domestic product (GDP) grew at an average rate of 
about 7.5% per year, and in 2002 was an estimated 5.7%.1 Agriculture accounts for about 22% 
of GDP. Per capita GDP almost doubled during the last decade, and the ratio of domestic 
savings to GDP increased by 2.5 times. Capital formation also almost doubled during this 
period. The economic slowdown that started in 2000 and was accentuated after 11 September 
2001 has dampened GDP growth in recent years. Foreign direct investment has slackened 
since its peak in the mid-1990s, largely due to perceptions that the cost of doing business in 
Viet Nam is high and that the Government is not willing to accelerate economic reforms. 
Nevertheless,  macroeconomic  indicators  such  as  inflation,  fiscal  deficits,  current  account 
deficits, and external debt are within manageable limits. 
 
3.  The incidence of poverty had been cut in half, from about 70% in 1990 to 37% in 2000. 
Rural poverty was reduced from 66% in 1993 to 45% in 1998. There has also been significant 
improvement in social indicators, with almost universal primary education access, and reduced 
incidence of infant mortality, under-five mortality, child malnutrition, and maternal mortality. 
However, there are major challenges in reducing poverty further. The incidence of rural poverty 
is much higher, and about 90% of the total poor population reside in rural areas. Poor villages 
and communes lack basic infrastructure and health facilities. Poverty incidence is higher in the 
northern areas (60%) and among ethnic minorities (75%).  
 
4.  Agricultural growth and rural poverty reduction have also been impressive over the last 
decade.  Growth  in  agricultural  production  averaged  4-5%  per  annum,  and  the  value  of 
agricultural output (80% in the form of crops and livestock, with the remainder from forestry and 
fisheries) grew 4.2% per year (Appendix 1). Agricultural growth was among the highest in the 
world during the 1990s, comparable with that in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). This 
growth was mainly due to market-oriented reforms that recognized the farm household as the 
key  unit  of  production,  liberalized  land-use  rights,  and  liberalized  decision  making  on  the 
purchase of inputs and sale of outputs. The ratio of cultivatable land per person is very low, 
suggesting that Viet Nam has a comparative advantage in production that maximizes value-
added per unit of land. Agriculture will continue to grow at a lower rate than industry and 
services; thus, acceleration of employment in rural services and industry is essential to minimize 
widening income disparities. Rice production (accounting for 60% of the cultivated area) grew at 
4.3%  during  the  1990s  due  to  increases  in  yield  and  cropping  intensity.  The  growth  in 
agricultural exports was also noteworthy. The value of agricultural exports grew at over 13% per 
year  during  this  period,  and  is  currently  about  $4.4  billion  per  year,  more  than  60%  of 
agricultural  GDP.  Rice,  coffee,  rubber,  cashews,  tea,  pepper,  and  seafood  are  the  major 
agricultural export items.

5.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) contributed to sector growth in the 1990s and the 
resultant reduction in rural poverty through the Agriculture Sector Program.2  This program had 
three components: (i) market orientation and efficiency, (ii) rural financial intermediation, and (iii) 
land  tenure.  The  program  was  rated  as  successful  in  increasing  market  orientation  and 
increasing rice production and exports, fertilizer imports; providing sustainable banking services 
to farmers including the poor; and increasing the issue of land use certificates for agricultural 
land and forestland.3 However, there remains some unfinished business in terms of complete 
market liberalization, access to credit, and land use rights. These are discussed below. 
 
B.  Issues and Opportunities 
1.  Problem Analysis 
6.  The past agricultural strategy was largely successful in generating and sustaining self-
sufficiency in food, expanding exports, increasing rural employment, and reducing rural poverty. 
However, the strategy is no longer sufficient to ensure future sustained agricultural growth in 
productivity and poverty reduction, because of declining (i) returns to labor, (ii) rice demand and 
exports due to low quality, and (iii) returns to irrigation infrastructure where rice is the dominant 
output. Also, growth in agriculture value-added declined from a high of 5.2% in 1999 to 2.3% in 
2001, and an estimated 2.1% in 2002.4  In contrast, industry and services experienced higher 
and increasing growth rates in this period. Viet Nam has been a successful exporter of low-
quality rice (e.g., high quantity of broken rice to Africa, Indonesia, and Philippines), coffee, 
rubber, cashew, tea, and black pepper. Viet Nam has not been successful in producing higher 
quality and higher priced agricultural commodities for export. As a result, while export volumes 
of these major commodities have continued to rise since 2000, export values and revenues 
have fallen due to low prices for rice, coffee, and tea in international markets.5 This situation is 
expected to continue in the medium term. Agricultural value-added per hectare (ha) is relatively 
high in Viet Nam by international standards (about $1,000/ha). However, the small size of the 
average farm (0.14 ha/capita) means that value-added per person is low ($140/person). A new 
strategy based on crop diversification and growth in high-quality and high-value products is 
needed. It will require shifting the focus from a primary commodity to a finished or intermediate 
product, and from production volume to quality value addition. 
 
7.  The  core  sector  problems  are  low  productivity  and  profitability,  lack  of  production 
diversity, low quality, and low competitiveness of the agricultural system. The causes of these 
problems  include  (i)  low  agricultural  diversification;  (ii)  weak  integration  with  postharvest 
systems  and  response  to  market  quality  requirements;  (iii)  poor  management  of  natural 
resources; (iv) low private sector investment in agricultural processing, trade, and input supply; 
and (v) weak stakeholder participation in efforts to improve extension and production. The major 
factors  contributing  to  low  productivity  and  low  agricultural  diversification  include 
(i) underdeveloped  and  weak  research  and  extension,  (ii)  underdeveloped  seed  production 
systems,  (iii)  restricted  land  use  rights,  (iv)  limited  access  to  financial  services,  and

(v) deteriorating and inefficient irrigation systems that require upgrading. Agricultural growth has 
relied increasingly on intensification and diversification. Intensification has expanded production 
but has also led to some soil degradation problems, particularly in upland areas. Maintenance of 
soil fertility is more difficult in upland areas. A major factor inhibiting private sector investment in

discussed below, SOE reforms with donor support and new Government policies to provide

bias against private sector involvement in marketing, trade, and production activities.  
 
8.   Agricultural research in Viet Nam is characterized by a fragmentation of efforts. About 
37  research  institutes  with  small  budgets  exist.  Their  concentration  in  the  Red  River  and 
Mekong  Deltas,  with  insufficient  representation  in  other  agroecological  zones,  limits  the 
relevance  of  research  results.  Viet  Nam  spends  only  about  0.3%  of  agricultural  GDP  on 
research, compared with 0.6% in the PRC and 1.4% in Thailand. Other problems are poor 
coordination  among  research  institutions,  weak  linkages  with  extension,  a  shortage  of 
sufficiently  qualified  researchers  and  extension  agents,  poorly  maintained  research 
infrastructure,  and  insufficient  involvement  of  stakeholders.  On  the  other  hand,  irrigation 
absorbs the largest share (50%) of the state budget to agriculture; most (90%) of this is used for 
capital expenditures. As a result, operation and maintenance are neglected. 
 
9.  The national extension system created recently in 1993 is operational in only 50% of the 
communes  (collection  of  villages).  The  farmer-agent  ratio  is  estimated  at  1,250:1.  Other 
constraints include a top-down approach in dealing with farmers, insufficient knowledge and 
skills  in  effective  communication,  poor  technological  recommendations,  lack  of  funding  for 
effective operations (despite the fact that provincial governments provide about 50% of annual 
budgets), and ineffective use of mass media and information technology. Public expenditure on 
agricultural extension in 2002 was only D441 billion ($29 million) or 0.4% of agricultural GDP. 
This is very low compared with that in neighboring PRC, Thailand, and Malaysia. 
 
10.  Improved seed is produced by a variety of organizations, including universities, research 
institutes, public seed agencies, and private seed companies. Because of limited funding for 
breeding and research operations, research institutes supplement their budgets with the sale of 
seed directly to both seed companies and farmers. Quality control is insufficient and limited to 
testing  by  the  National  Center  for  Variety  Evaluation  and  Seed  Certification.  The  Danish 
International Development Agency (Danida) is currently funding a seed project as part of the 
Agriculture Sector Program Support, with a focus on seed certification, quality control and 
regulation, seed research and pathology, and seed production and processing. Efforts are 
focused on rice and maize seeds, the two most important food crops, and institutional support at 
national, provincial, and on-farm levels. De facto restrictions prevent trade in seed between 
provinces. As a result of these problems, the use of certified seed is small in the Mekong River 
Delta, rice yields have stagnated over the past 5 years, and maize yields are low (2.5 tons/ha) 
despite the increasing adoption of improved seed. Subsidies on the commercial production of 
hybrid  rice  and  maize  seeds,  administered  by  provincial  governments  and  the  national 
extension service, are becoming increasingly unnecessary given the widespread adoption of 
hybrids. Such subsidies divert needed funds away from agricultural extension to small farmers, 
and discourage to some extent private seed company sales of these hybrids. However, the 
promotion of hybrid rice seeds remains an important part of poverty reduction programs for poor 
and subsistence farmers in mountainous regions (Appendix 1).

11.  The major constraints affecting postharvest systems include (i) continued discrimination 
against private enterprises, (ii) incomplete market liberalization, (iii) inadequate access to land 
and credit for private investment, (iv) lack of market information and support systems, and (v) 
lack of grades and standards. The role of SOEs in agriculture has diminished, but they still 
dominate processing, exports, and imports. Exports of rice, coffee, tea, cashew, pepper, and 
rubber, and imports of fertilizer are carried out almost exclusively by SOEs. SOEs also enjoy 
preferential access to credit and land. In some cases, these enterprises continue to receive 
special  assistance  even  after  equitization.  On  the  other  hand,  credit  and  land  availability 
seriously constrain private enterprises wishing to expand their operations. Since the late 1980s, 
Viet Nam’s trade policy has been extensively liberalized, resulting in the dramatic growth of 
exports and imports. Following the Asian crisis of 1997, however, reforms have stalled, some 
with policy reversals. Fertilizer and sugar are subject to “managed imports,” although the policy 
is protectionist only in the case of sugar. Vegetable oil is also subject to managed imports under 
“temporary legislation.” Imports of seeds, breeding animals, and other agricultural inputs require 
government approval, often resulting in delays. 
 
12.  The existing Land Law limits the use rights of agricultural land to 3 ha. This has restricted 
land  market  transfers.  Because  households  attempt  to  evade  these  restrictions,  most 
transactions are unregistered and official information about land distribution becomes unreliable. 
Restrictions on the conversion of paddy land limit other more profitable uses of land and slow 
down the rate of crop diversification. Previous policy changes have lifted several of these 
restrictions.  However,  using  land  as  collateral  for  bank  credit  is  problematic  because  of 
difficulties in foreclosure.  
 
13.  Regarding  rural  financial  services,  the  Viet  Nam  Bank  for  Agriculture  and  Rural 
Development (VBARD) has performed well in providing lending and savings deposit services to 
small farmers and microenterprises with very small operations and average loan sizes. VBARD 
has managed strong growth in lending while keeping repayment rates high. However, its loan 
portfolio to SOEs has not performed well. VBARD’s capital adequacy ratio (CAR) is below 
accepted international norms (8%) largely due to poor performing loans to SOEs. Despite 
VBARD’s focus on small farmers and microenterprises, only one third of rural households have 
access to formal credit in a given year. Most of this credit is short term (less than 1 year), and 
the average loan size is small (about $300), reflecting the focus on small farmers and other 
borrowers. Access to larger loans on medium and long terms to develop SMEs has been 
limited. Interest rate ceilings in the past prevented VBARD and other banks from offering credit 
to riskier or smaller borrowers, as well as limited their ability to mobilize savings. The Bank for 
the Poor is now completely separate from VBARD, with its own capital, ownership, and mandate 
to lend exclusively to the poor. Favored treatment of SOEs in the past has limited the pool of 
capital available to farmers and SMEs. However, VBARD in 2002 enacted a new policy that will 
expand its limited SME portfolio and reduce its SOE portfolio over time. 
 
2.  Opportunities 
14.  Assisted  by  ADB  in  preparing  this  sector  development  program,  the  Ministry  of 
Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD) developed a new agriculture and rural development 
plan and strategy for 2001-2010. The strategy focuses on (i) intensifying agricultural production; 
(ii) diversifying into higher value crops and new markets; (iii) promoting off-farm employment; 
and  (iv)  targeting  poverty,  especially  in  remote  and  upland  areas.  The  instruments  for 
implementing  this  strategy  include  (i)  science  and  technology  advancements;  (ii)  market- 
supporting infrastructure and institutions; (iii) private sector investment with a focus on SMEs 
and  off-farm  employment;  (iv)  rural  infrastructure;  and  (v)  participation  of  concerned

approved this strategy in mid-2001 as part of its 10-year development plan. Some of the 
quantitative targets over the next decade include (i) sustaining an annual growth rate of 4.5% in 
agriculture; (ii) increasing rice paddy production from 34 million tons to 40 million tons; (iii) 
increasing the value of total agricultural exports from $4.4 billion to $9 billion; (iv) decreasing 
rural poverty from 45% to 27%; (v) sustaining an annual growth rate of 9-12% for rural industry 
and services; (vi) increasing the share of industry, trade, and services in the rural economy from 
30% to 45%; and (vii) increasing the average product value of an agricultural laborer from $310 
to $1,500. 
 
15.  The  recently  approved  Poverty  Reduction  Partnership  Agreement  between  the 
Government and the ADB also identifies several strategies to reduce poverty: (i) sustainable 
growth,  by  reforming  agricultural  research  and  extension,  increasing  private  investment  in 
agricultural  processing,  agricultural  market  support,  improving  financial  infrastructure,  and 
encouraging a competitive domestic private sector; (ii) inclusive social development through 
secondary education and primary health care interventions; (iii) improved governance through 
public administration reform; and (iv) regional focus on the central region. This agreement is 
consistent  with  the  Government’s  Comprehensive  Poverty  Reduction  and  Growth  Strategy 
approved in 2002. 
 
16.  Given the Government’s, ADB’s and other aid agencies’ planned programs in irrigation, 
forestry, land markets and tenure,6 rural poverty reduction, and rural infrastructure, the proposed 
Agriculture Sector Development Program (ASDP) will focus on gaps in science and technology, 
technology  transfer,  increased  quality  and  value-added  production  through  SME 
agroprocessing,  and  market  information.  Major  opportunities  exist  to  increase  agricultural 
productivity, growth, efficiency, and competitiveness of agricultural outputs and value-added 
products, which will lead to sustainable increases in rural incomes. A major factor in increasing 
agricultural productivity is the application of science and technology. New technologies in the 
form of higher-yielding seeds, improved animal husbandry, and integrated pest management 
result in higher productivity and, where appropriate market conditions exist, higher income. 
Strategies  for  raising  agricultural  productivity,  particularly  for  poor  households,  include  (i) 
restructuring and expanding public support for agricultural research, (ii) expanding access to 
credit in a sustainable way, (iii) improving seed quality through agricultural research and seed 
certification, (iv) increasing labor productivity through training and extension, and (v) improving 
market intelligence.

system that can develop and adapt cutting-edge technology. This requires (i) clear roles and 
responsibilities of research institutes to avoid duplication; (ii) increased funding; (iii) increased

agents and farmer representatives to researchers on the value of ongoing research and on the

18.  Improving the productivity of agricultural labor is one of the most important strategies for 
raising rural standards of living. Increasing labor productivity will raise the incomes of the 
majority of the rural poor. In the medium and long run, the extension service should adopt the 
following features: (i) increase the size of the extension service to fill gaps at the commune

improve the extension services, and provide feedback from mass organizations, nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs), and private sector input suppliers.  
 
19.  Facilitating the growth of rural and agricultural SMEs and improving their efficiency to 
increase the value of agricultural and rural-based production and to stimulate growth in rural 
employment, present an opportunity to increase the investment and participation of private 
enterprises and decrease the dominant role of SOEs in processing, marketing, and exporting 
crops such as rice, coffee, rubber, and tea.7 The Government is not only reducing the access of 
SOEs to preferential credit and land, and requiring SOEs to be self-supporting, but also actively 
promoting SME development by (i) improving access to credit through state-owned commercial 
banks; (ii) rapidly expanding access to state land in the form of rural industrial parks, rented out 
with the provision of infrastructure (roads, electricity, water, etc.); and (iii) simplifying taxation of 
SME and cracking down on corruption and fraud of public officials. Government activities to 
facilitate growth in private investment include financial services, market information, export 
promotion, establishing grades and standards, inspection services, disease control, strategic 
and  applied  research,  and  improved  management  of  the  natural  resource  base  on  which 
production and rural SME activities depend. 
 
20.  The long-run objective for agricultural credit is to develop a sustainable system that 
mobilizes  savings  from  rural  and  urban  households  and  provides  unsubsidized  credit  to

associated with the loan. In the short and medium terms, VBARD requires more flexibility in 
setting interest rates so as to profitably lend to an expanded set of borrowers. It also requires 
recapitalization and reimbursement for eligible nonperforming loans. The Government should 
discontinue the practice of directing loans to SOEs.8

22.  Sustainable growth of the agriculture sector is a prerequisite for economic growth and 
poverty reduction in Viet Nam. Despite progress in agricultural production and export growth 
and in liberalizing commodity, land, and credit markets in recent years, rural poverty remains 
high and private sector investment remains small. Growth in the past was the result of (i) 
reliance on higher input use (labor, capital, and water); (ii) policy reforms in land, markets, and 
trade; and (iii) high public investment, mainly in the form of irrigation and roads. The annual 
sector growth of about 6% over the past decade was largely attributed to increased use of labor 
(14%), land (11%), basic intermediate inputs such as fertilizer (51%), tractors (14%), and water 
pumps for irrigation (5%), with total factor productivity through other technology accounting for 
only 4%.9 Thus, the sector strategy of the 1990s will not be able to sustain growth in the future 
because (i) the potential for expanding the rural labor force and land under cultivation is limited; 
(ii) new investment in irrigation exhibits decreasing marginal returns as the stock of irrigation 
capital is already very high and requires increased operation, maintenance, and management in 
addition to new expansion for irrigation, water supply, and flood control; and (iii) rice export 
revenue is declining due to poor quality and dependence on low-end markets. Viet Nam is 
already  experiencing  difficulties  in  competition  for  markets  in  rice,  coffee,  and  other 
unprocessed commodities. 
 
23.  A new strategy is needed to sustain agricultural growth in the future. Future growth will 
depend on growth in productivity, diversification, quality improvement, and emphasis on related 
technology. The Government’s strategy for 2001-2010, supported by ADB and other sources, is 
the  plan  for  agriculture  in  Viet  Nam.  Policy  makers  in  the  Government  are  interested  in 
sustaining growth, employment, and exports in agriculture so as to reduce rural poverty. The 
strategy includes effecting policy reforms for commercial agriculture, livestock, water resources, 
and forestry. Policy reforms in the development and use of technologies through research and 
extension and improved access to credit by SMEs are expected to (i) improve yields; (ii) foster 
diversification into available markets for higher value crops; (iii) improve the quality of products 
such as rice, coffee, livestock products, fruits, and vegetables that respond to and meet the 
requirements of specific, well-targeted domestic and export markets; (iv) increase value-added 
production (e.g., processed and packaged cashew, rice noodles, and brand name tea and 
coffee);  and  (v)  expand  rural  industries,  infrastructure,  and  services.  With  increased 
understanding of and responsiveness to different markets, competitiveness in export markets is 
expected to improve. The consequence—increased employment, and reduced indebtedness 
and sales of landholdings—will have beneficial impacts on rural poverty. 
 
24.  Major factors contributing to low agricultural productivity, quality, and diversity include 
limited (i) understanding of potential market opportunities, (ii) access to appropriate research

25.  Private enterprises wishing to expand their operations are seriously constrained by lack 
of credit and market information. To take advantage of value-added market opportunities, the 
Government will need to more actively support trade promotion and assist the private sector with 
product-specific market research. Capacity building for MARD and the provincial and improved 
coordination in trade promotion functions (including market analysis, exhibitions, and information

addressed the financial needs of these SMEs, except for microenterprises and very small SMEs 
under previous ADB financing. The provision of market information and medium- and long-term 
funds will facilitate and accelerate investment in agro-industry. It will also encourage the adoption 
of new technologies crucial to the success of these enterprises in a competitive environment. 
Program  reforms  and  investments  intend  to  provide  the  SMEs  with  agricultural  market 
information, increase access to medium- and long-term credit, and encourage the development 
of SMEs in agro-industry. 
 
26.  VBARD, the leading commercial bank in rural areas, recently started lending to private 
SMEs. Its new strategy, consistent with the Government’s 10-year development plan, is to 
support SMEs while reducing lending over time to SOEs. By supporting VBARD, the Program 
will be able to reach a major share of existing and potential agro-industry SMEs and partially 
address the financing gap. Credit to SMEs will facilitate the adoption of relevant technologies 
generated by the research institutes and promoted by the extension service. VBARD needs 
policy reforms to strengthen its financial performance and capacity to deliver sustainable credit 
and expand services to SMEs. The relatively high level of liquidity in the banking system in Viet 
Nam is mainly due to short-term deposits. Medium-term and long-term funds are needed for 
investments. Funds provided by ASDP will meet this need, as well as improve the balance 
between  short-term  and  long-term  funds  in  the  banking  sector.  ASDP  will  help  create  an

diversified portfolios in VBARD and help make it less risk exposed. Being long-term, ADB funds 
will  strengthen  VBARD  financially  by  reducing  its  duration  and  interest-variation  risks  and 
improving its fund management.

III.  THE PROPOSED SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM 
A.  Objectives and Scope 
28.  The Program has been designed to assist the Government address declining growth in 
the  agriculture  sector  and  rural  economy  by  addressing  key  constraints  to  agricultural 
productivity and competitiveness. Beneficiaries will have opportunities to increase incomes and 
employment  and  improve  the  quality  of  life  through  access  to  strengthened  and  more 
responsive agricultural support services and capital. Private sector agro-industries will receive 
incentives to increase investment and employment through improved access to capital. The 
objectives of the Program will be to facilitate increases in agricultural productivity, profitability, 
and competitiveness in domestic and export markets by increasing the capacity of research and 
extension  to  deliver  relevant  technology,  improving  access  to  information,  and  increasing 
access of private sector SMEs to capital. The expected outcomes are increased agricultural 
diversification, improved postharvest systems, reduced vulnerability of rural households, and 
greater participation of rural households in sector development efforts. ASDP includes specific 
reform measures to (i) strengthen support services in science and technology (research and 
extension);  and  (ii)  promote  the  development  of  agro-industry  SMEs.10  The  chronology  of 
designing ASDP is in Appendix 2. 
 
29.  ASDP consists of two components with common objectives: (i) a program or policy 
reform loan, and (ii) a project or agro-industry SME loan. Policy reforms in research, extension, 
market information, and financial services to agro-industry SMEs are required to implement the 
Government’s 10-year (2001-2010) development strategy and to permit meaningful investments 
in science and technology, and private sector SME development. The project loan, consisting of 
financial support to VBARD to provide medium- and long-term credit for the rapidly expanding 
agro-industry SMEs, is consistent with the Program’s objectives and is required to help meet the 
rapidly growing demand for SME financial services.

IV.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits 
74.  Given the limited growth prospects from further increased use of physical factors and 
basic intermediate inputs, growth in productivity through access to and application of improved 
technology, information, and capital for private sector SMEs is key to maintaining growth in Viet 
Nam’s  agriculture  sector.  Consequently,  the  strengthening  of  agricultural  research  and 
extension  through  policy  and  institutional  reforms  is  expected  to  contribute  significantly  to 
sustaining sector growth targets over the next 10 years. Due to the exogenous macroeconomic 
and microeconomic influences on Viet Nam’s agriculture sector (e.g., time required for market 
and land reforms to take full effect, and sectorwide effects of world commodity prices and 
markets) and the indirect impacts from institutional reforms in science and technology, future

21
contributions  to  agricultural  growth  from  the  Program  cannot  be  forecast  quantitatively. 
Nevertheless,  the  future  and  critical  roles  of  access  to  and  application  of  technology  and 
information in productivity and quality improvements, and value addition by farmers and agro-
industry  enterprises  in  Viet  Nam  are  demonstrated  in  program  preparation  studies.20  The 
impressive sector growth over the past decade was largely achieved through increased use of 
labor,  land,  basic  intermediate  inputs  (e.g.,  fertilizer),  irrigation,  and  machinery,  with  other 
technology accounting for only 4% of growth. With limited options for further increasing the use 
of these inputs, future growth will depend on growth in total factor productivity, diversification, 
and quality and technology improvements. By more effectively identifying, testing, adapting, and 
disseminating new and appropriate technologies and having them adopted by farmers and 
enterprises, the Program will significantly contribute to the Government’s annual growth targets 
of 4.5% for the sector. The sector growth rate required to equate to the minimum targeted 
incremental annual recurrent expenditure on research and extension of $5.5 million is less than 
0.01% per annum (i.e., the break-even growth rate), a small fraction of the targeted 4.5% sector 
growth rate. Similarly, total estimated adjustment costs from institutional reforms were less than 
1.3% of the sector GDP in 2000. 
 
75.  Benefits to farmers and enterprises are likely to be realized through increased access to 
and application of improved technology. These benefits include (i) increased productivity of 
existing areas under production; (ii) increased value through improved quality of commodities; 
(iii) lower risk and avoidance of production loss; (iv) incremental production and processing; (v) 
increased net farm incomes and enterprise gross profits; and (vi) increased employment of rural 
people, including the poor. These increases are attributed to (i) acquisition and development of 
technologies  by  the  research  institutes;  (ii)  more  effective  dissemination  to  farmers  by 
agricultural extension agents, input suppliers, and traders; and (iii) farmers’ improved capacity to 
respond to markets due to access to better market information and understanding of market 
opportunities. The full benefits of a rationalized and cost-effective research system that is more 
oriented to market trends and farmer needs, and an expanded and participatory extension 
system are likely to be realized in the medium term. However, acquisition and transfer of 
existing  proven  technologies  could  result  in  early  benefits.  Expanded  and  better  targeted 
services resulting from the reforms will benefit subsistence, semicommercial, and commercial 
farmers in irrigated, rain-fed, and mountainous areas. In addition, expanded support services, 
while requiring additional overall fiscal resources, will be more cost-effective due to service 
rationalization (e.g., reducing the number of research institutes), will reduce overheads and 
duplication of services and expenditure reallocation (e.g., from national research institutes to 
regional and commodity- or disciplinary-specific institutes).  
 
76.  The provision of increased funding to research, extension, market information systems, 
and capital for value-adding agro-industry SMEs will facilitate accelerated investment in agro-
industry  and  the  adoption  of  new  technologies  crucial  to  their  success  in  a  competitive 
environment. Policy makers in Viet Nam see the rapid expansion of SMEs in the rural sector as an 
effective and largely neglected mechanism to increase employment and expand growth through 
private investments. The growth of rural SMEs will foster crop diversification, agroprocessing, 
good-quality products, and exports. These SMEs share a large unmet demand for credit as 
demonstrated in program preparation studies (footnotes 18 and 20, and the analysis of demand 
for SME credit). The most effective conduit for providing agro-industry SME credit is VBARD with 
its current SME operations through its effective network of over 1,600 rural branch offices and 
25,000  employees.  Access  to  appropriate  medium-  and  long-term  funds  will  encourage

B.  Impacts 
77.  The Program will continue the support for market orientation in agriculture that the 
Government has embraced since doi moi. The Program will specifically target restructuring and 
institutional building in science and technology that is necessary for liberalization and market 
orientation to have sustainable benefits. For the high levels of growth achieved in the past to 
continue into the future, a new strategy for growth in agriculture should be developed. The new 
strategy should be based on the application of science and technology to boost productivity, 
particularly of the poor, and vigorous promotion of private SMEs, particularly in agro-industry.  
 
1.  Impact of Agricultural Research Restructuring 
78.  The direct impacts of the Program will be changes to the structure and operations of the 
system  of  research  institutes  under  MARD.  These  changes  will  be  implemented  in  an 
incremental fashion in the course of the Program. The long-term impact of changes to the 
structure and operations of the research institutes will be to build an effective and sustainable 
agricultural research system able to contribute to the generation of sustainable technologies 
appropriate to the majority of farmers in Viet Nam.  
 
79.  Changes in structure will involve merging some research institutes, redesignating a 
number  of  institutes,  closing  some,  and  refocusing  research  effort  along  regional  and 
commodity group-based lines. These changes in structure may have impacts on the staff of the 
research  institutes,  who  may  be  redesignated,  relocated,  or  even  retrenched.  Changes  in 
operations  of  the  institutes  will  include  increasing  the  level  of  funding  provided  by  the 
Government to support research, increasing the autonomy of the research institutes, decreasing 
their commercial nonresearch activities, and increasing the linkages between research and 
extension. The changes in the operations of the research institutes will have an impact on the 
capacity of the research institutes to carry out efficient and timely research relevant to the needs 
of a variety of stakeholders in agriculture. 
 
2.  Impact of Expansion of Market Information Systems 
80.  Replicating the existing pilot ICARD market information systems and analysis for farmers 
and private sector agro-industry SMEs is expected to increase farmers and SME access to 
knowledge, and ability to respond to existing and new market opportunities. This will help 
reduce the current overproduction of some basic commodities, facilitate greater focusing on 
untapped and value-added domestic and export markets, and help farmers and enterprises 
meet the conditions of buyers in terms of price, quality, and supply consistency.

medium-term impacts on extension services at the national, provincial, district, and commune

SECTOR AND SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
1.  Agriculture plays a dominant role in the economy of Viet Nam, as it accounts for about 
30% of gross domestic product (GDP), 70% of employment, and 50% of export value. Although 
these shares will decline over the coming years as they have done slowly over the past decade, 
the agriculture sector will remain at the core of the country’s economy in the next decade. 
Further, since poverty is mainly a rural problem, attacking poverty and promoting economic 
growth and national development will be critical challenges for agriculture. At the same time, a 
major challenge is stimulating growth in investment and off-farm employment through private 
sector industries and other rural enterprises. 
 
A.  Past Performance 
 
2.  The  past  performance  of  the  agriculture  sector  over  the  last  15  years  since  the 
introduction of doi moi (economic reform) in 1986 has been impressive. Growth in agriculture 
averaged 4.3% of GDP during 1980-1990, and increased to 4.9% of GDP during 1990–1999. 
This  growth  was  higher  than  that  in  India,  Indonesia,  Philippines,  and  Thailand,  and  was 
comparable with agricultural growth in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). The value of 
agricultural exports  rose  from  $1.1  billion  in 1990  to  $4.3  billion  in 1998.  The sources  of 
agricultural growth were large increases in yields and production of rice, maize, industrial crops, 
fruits, vegetables, livestock, and seafood. These gains were attributed to policy reforms in 
markets,  land  and  trade,  widespread  use  of  improved  seeds  (including  hybrid  seed)  and 
livestock breeds, heavy application of fertilizers and pesticides, and large-scale investments in 
irrigation and road infrastructure. The Mekong River Delta and Red River Delta are the two main 
areas that experienced rapid agricultural growth and improvement in farm incomes since they 
are well served by irrigation and road infrastructure, banking services, and agricultural support 
services. Other areas, particularly the northern uplands, the interior of the north central coast, 
and northern part of the central highlands, experienced much slower growth, and therefore 
suffer from a high level of poverty.  
 
1.  Crop Subsector 
 
3.  The crop subsector is the largest subsector contributing about 64% of the total output in 
agriculture,  followed  by  livestock  (18%),  fisheries  (14%),  and  forestry  (4%).1  In  the  crop 
subsector, rice dominates agricultural output since it accounts for about 7.3 million hectares (ha) 
or 60% of agricultural land, 44% of household agricultural revenue, 75% of calorific intake, and 
30% of agricultural exports. During 1990-1998, rice production increased from 19.2 million tons 
to 29.1 million tons, an increase of about 4.3% per annum. This increase was attributed to 
increases in both yields (2.7% per annum) and cropping intensity (2.0% per annum). The 
Mekong River Delta provides about 52% of total rice production in the country and is the main 
source of rice exports, whereas all other regions are either self-sufficient or rice-deficit areas. 
However, yields in the Mekong River Delta have been stagnant at about 4 tons per ha during 
the past 5 years, suggesting that agricultural intensification in the region has caused soil fertility 
to decline. 
 
4.  Another important food crop is maize, which is widely grown in upland areas. During 
1990-1998, maize production increased by 8.9% per annum, from 0.7 million tons to 1.6 million 
tons resulting from an increase in yields (6%) and cropped area (4.8%). The average yield of 
maize at about 3.1 tons per ha is low, considering that 63% of the total maize area is planted to

growing  sugarcane.  The  large increase  in  sugarcane  production,  primarily  in  the  south,  is

sugarcane growers and sugar mills at the expense of consumers and food processors that use 
sugar. 
 
6.  During the last few years, the production of fruits and vegetables has also increased 
rapidly to meet the rising demand among high-income urban consumers and export markets. 
This development is contributing to farm income, public health and well-being, and agricultural

fold since 1990, while the production of longan, rambutan, and litchi has grown at over 20% 
since 1995. On the other hand, pineapple output has fallen by over 40% with the loss of the 
Eastern European export markets, while banana production has stagnated. The total area under 
vegetables was estimated at 401,000 ha, while the total area under fruits reached 438,000 ha in 
1998. Although fruit and vegetable exports have increased slowly in volume (1% annually since 
1990), the export value has risen quickly (15% annually), reflecting a shift to higher-value 
products. The total value of fruits and vegetable exports in 2000 was estimated at $210 million. 
 
2.  Agricultural Research 
 
7.  The present system of agricultural research in Viet Nam consists of 37 institutions and 
12 agricultural universities under five ministries with overlapping functions, limited scientific 
coordination and cooperation, and uneven geographical distribution. The Ministry of Agriculture 
and Rural Development (MARD) remains the main ministry in charge of agricultural research 
since it supervises about 86% of the research institutes and 2 of the 12 agricultural universities. 
Most of the institutes are located in the Red River Delta and the Mekong River Delta. Many 
provinces do not have easy access to any local research institutions. Centralization of research 
activities and management makes it difficult for the institutes to address poverty reduction and 
environmental  sustainability  issues.  The  institutes  are  also  underfunded.  In  2000,  public 
expenditure for agricultural research was D245 billion ($16 million). Given that Viet Nam’s 
agricultural GDP for 2000 was estimated at D100 trillion ($7 billion), the spending of MARD on

less government interference, will have limited impact in promoting private research. However,

international research centers, (iii) autonomy of agricultural research institutes to obtain funding 
from the private sector, and (iv) protection of intellectual property rights will help stimulate 
private involvement in research. 
 
3.  Agricultural Extension 
 
10.  The current national agricultural extension consists of central, provincial, district, and 
commune units. At the central level, the Department of Agriculture and Forestry Extension 
(DAFE)  has  overall  responsibility  for  coordinating,  planning,  monitoring,  evaluating,  and

and regulatory roles in managing national agricultural production. These roles pose a major 
constraint to the effective functioning of DAFE as a national extension agency. The provincial 
government  is  responsible  for  implementing  extension  through  its  district  and  commune 
extension networks.  
 
11.  The  national  extension  service  suffers  from  a  scarcity  of  staff  and  limited  financial 
resources. The total number of extension staff in the country is about 8,000. Given that there 
are about 10.7 million farmers in the country, the ratio of extension staff to number of farmers is 
only 1:1,340. About 50% of the communes do not have any extension staff. In 2002, the total

from the central government, and D375 billion from the provincial governments (largely from the 
collection of land tax). Although this budget is D83 billion ($5.5 million) higher from the previous 
year’s budget, it is still low to meet the requirements for effective agricultural extension. Most of

5.  Seed Subsidies 
 
17.  There are three types of subsidy on hybrid seeds: (i) a subsidy from the provincial 
governments for the commercial production of hybrid rice and maize seeds in four provinces; 
(ii) a subsidy from the national Government, implemented through DAFE, for a pilot program in 
10 provinces to encourage farmers to grow and sell hybrid rice seeds to seed companies; and 
(iii)  a  poverty  reduction  program  administered  by  the  provincial  governments  to  provide 
subsidized hybrid rice seeds to poor and subsistence farmers in 18 mountainous provinces. The 
total amount spent on these subsidies in 2002 was $4.5 million equivalent: (i) $1.3 million for the 
provincial commercial production program, (ii) $0.5 million for the national pilot program, and (iii) 
$2.7 million for the provincial poverty reduction program. 
 
18.  Viet  Nam  currently  produces  over  50%  of  its  hybrid  maize  seed  requirements 
domestically, so there is agreement within the Government that subsidies are no longer needed 
to  promote  its  commercial  production.  The  rationale  for  the  subsidies  on  the  commercial 
production of hybrid rice seeds is (i) import substitution to reduce dependence on imported 
Chinese rice hybrid seeds, and (ii) price stabilization to counter occasional high prices in the 
PRC. Viet Nam currently plants about 17,000 tons of hybrid rice seed yearly, but produces only 
2,500–3,000 tons of hybrid seed domestically. The balance is imported from the PRC, usually 
the  male  and  female  lines  of  relatively  low-yielding  hybrids  from  private  seed  companies. 
Commercial seed companies in Viet Nam then cross these lines and the resulting hybrid seed is 
sold in domestic markets. The current price of imported hybrid rice seed is about $1,300 per ton 
and the 2002 import bill was about $22 million. The current price of hybrid seed grown in Viet 
Nam is about 20% less than the import price. The Government's objective is to produce about 
50%  of  total  domestic  demand  by  2005  (about  10,000  tons).  In  addition  to  promoting 
commercial production of hybrid rice seed, for which subsidies will end in 2003, MARD has 
been financing a pilot extension program whereby farmers are provided free hybrid seeds, seed 
treatments, and training. Seed companies choose these farmers, and the national extension 
service gives the farmer inputs and training for 2–3 years to grow seeds for sale to seed 
companies. This program is being promoted in 10 provinces where yields are highest. The

19.  The major rationale for promoting hybrid rice to poor and subsistence farmers is that 
hybrid rice seed outyields ordinary open-pollinated rice varieties by about 2:1 in mountainous 
areas where the poorest subsistence farmers are located. Such seeds are suitable for small 
landholdings (the average size is 500 square meters). MARD has estimated that doubling the 
crop yield for subsistence farmers in mountainous areas can reduce an average of 2 ha of 
slash-and-burn agriculture for every hectare of land planted to hybrid rice or maize. The rice 
subsidy for a poor farmer is spread over three crop seasons (the average is two rice crops per 
year) and comprises 100% of the price for the first rice crop, 50% for the second crop, 30% for 
the third crop, and 0% for the fourth crop onward. Poor farmers are usually able to sustain rice 
production after the termination of the subsidy since the quantity of hybrid rice seed required is 
so small: an average of 2 kilograms of rice seed, costing about $2 (equivalent to the price of two 
chickens). This poverty reduction program is financed entirely from the provincial budgets in 16 
northern provinces and 2 central provinces. 
 
6.  Rural Finance 
 
20.  Even though the three major rural financial institutions in Viet Nam, namely, the Vietnam 
Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (VBARD), the Viet Nam Bank for the Poor (VBP), 
and the People’s Credit Funds (PCF), have made considerable progress in outstanding loans 
growth, the needs of rural households for credit are still largely unmet. The country’s financial 
system consists of the formal, semiformal, and informal sectors. The formal sector reaches 
about one third of rural households with a small average loan size (about $300) and a short 
repayment period (less than 1 year). The remaining rural households obtain their credit from 
semiformal and informal sources. Less than one half of the larger and commercial farmers are 
able to obtain credit in a given  year. Other constraints limiting the emergence of a more 
developed rural finance system include the weak link between land and credit markets, interest 
rate controls, subsidized credit, favored treatment of SOEs, and prohibition on foreign banks to 
enter the land-mortgage market. 
 
21.  Even though land can be used as collateral in accessing bank credit, in practice this is 
not yet resulting in expanded rural credit. Banks limit the collateral to the amount of land rent 
already paid, implying that only insignificant amounts can be borrowed against the collateral. If 
the borrower cannot repay the debt, banks find themselves in a very difficult position to auction 
the land. This situation greatly limits the link between credit and land markets and retards the 
expansion of rural credit. 
 
22.  Control  of  interest  rates  on  loans  and  deposits  prevents  the  financial  system  from 
functioning effectively. When interest rates on deposits are limited, banking institutions find it 
difficult to mobilize savings. The liberalization of interest rates from June 2002 and the resultant 
increase  in  VBARD  interest  rates  will  improve  VBARD’s  financial  performance,  and  raise 
income and profitability.  
 
23.  The practice of subsidizing credit to the poor may inhibit the development of commercial 
banking and the emergence of durable financial institutions in remote areas. Subsidized credit is 
widely practiced by VBP, NGOs, mass organizations, and to some extent by VBARD in some of 
its programs. Experience with microfinance for the poor from Bangladesh and other countries 
suggest that a sustainable system could be developed using market interest rates. The dramatic 
increase in PCF’s lending program is probably the best evidence for the argument that there is

latent demand for credit at higher interest rates and that rural financial institutions can grow 
without subsidized interest rates. Interest rates charged by PCF are higher than what VBARD 
charges (1.2-1.3% for PCF versus 0.9-1.1% per month for VBARD). 
 
24.  Favored treatment for SOEs in rural credit does not bode well for expanding credit to 
rural households. Allocating credit to SOEs on the basis of directives from the central level has 
caused serious loan recovery problems for the commercial banking system as in the case of the 
sugar industry. Moreover, giving preferential treatment to SOEs restricts access to credit of 
millions of rural households, and small- and medium-sized enterprises. Within the central SOEs 
engaged in agriculture, about 17% incurred losses in 1998 with an average loss of D8.4 billion. 
Support given to loss-incurring SOEs results in unfair competition between private enterprises 
and  SOEs,  and  discourages  the  private  sector  from  investing  in  areas  where  SOEs  are 
dominant. 
 
B.  Future Challenges 
 
25.  Agricultural growth in Viet Nam over the past 15 years was the result of a combination of 
(i) institutional factors such as new incentive to farmers recognized by doi moi as autonomous 
economic agents; (ii) physical factors such as land, labor, and capital (mostly in the form of 
irrigation system); and (iii) intermediate inputs such as fertilizers and pesticides. The role of 
science and technology in explaining growth over the past 15 years has been relatively small, 
since most of the growth could be explained by increasing factors of production. This strategy is 
unlikely to sustain similar growth in the future for three reasons: (i) the labor force in agriculture 
is starting to decline and with very little land available per farmer, the attractiveness of farming 
will decline further; (ii) new investment in irrigation exhibits decreasing marginal returns as the 
stock of irrigation capital is already very high and requires increased repair and maintenance 
rather than new expansion, (iii) Viet Nam has already captured a large share of world rice 
markets so that both domestic and international demand for rice will start to grow at a much 
lower rate than in the past.  
 
26.  Future sustained growth in agriculture will have to come from an increasing demand 
(both in the country and internationally) for high-value agricultural products. That implies a more 
diversified agricultural system, where a variety of high-quality products are produced for the 
market. This will also imply a change from a perspective that is focused on production volume to 
increasing production values. Future agricultural growth will also require a policy environment 
that promotes competition and uses science and technology applied to agricultural production to 
meet the demand of a more sophisticated market. Policy reforms are required to address the 
weaknesses in agricultural research, agricultural extension, and rural finance. Competition will 
be necessary to lower production cost and thus capture higher market shares and profits in the 
international markets. Science and technology will be necessary to identify new production 
processes and innovative products that can increase productivity in the agricultural system to a 
much  larger  extent  than  addition  of  labor,  irrigated  land,  and  fertilizers.  Developing  agro-
industry, promoting private small- and medium-sized agro-industry enterprises, and supporting 
market infrastructure and institutions will be necessary to capture higher value-added from 
agricultural production. If all these requirements can be fulfilled, Viet Nam will be able to achieve 
a broad-based, market-oriented, and sustainable growth in agriculture in the next decade.

A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The proposed loans were screened for environmental impacts using matrices based on 
the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) Environmental Guidelines for Selected Agricultural and

1.  Program Loan 
 
2.  The program loan was screened for (i) the proposed sector policy actions, (ii) anticipated 
environmental impact, and (iii) the recommended environmental action to be taken. In general, 
the screening found the impacts of proposed reforms to be significant positive, unknown, or 
none. The screening did not find any significant negative environmental impacts due to the 
proposed policy reforms. 
 
3.  Significant positive impacts exist because the policy reforms have two characteristics 
that  support  sustainability:  elimination  of  market  distortions  and  participatory  planning. 
Economic policies that help eliminate market distortions generally stimulate growth and improve 
the environment. In many countries the reduction of subsidies on agricultural inputs has led to 
more efficient use of these resources and reduced surface water and groundwater pollution, 
improved air quality, and decreased the accumulation of toxic wastes. Moreover, non-distorting 
economic policies that stimulate economic growth by improving the allocation of resources 
generally create appropriate incentives for the protection of the environment. The program loan 
also proposes numerous interventions that will increase the participation of farmers (particularly 
ethnic groups, female, and people working in marginal farming conditions) in planning and 
decision  making.  Proposed  policies  also  support  more  on-farm  research  and  increased 
extension services. These types of activities weave local knowledge into the planning process—
a critical trait for environmentally sustainable and socially relevant agricultural development.

proposed policy reforms will specifically address environmental protection of natural ecosystems

VBARD’s guidelines for appraising loan applications clearly state that all loan applications must 
adhere  to  the  laws  and  regulations  of  the  Ministry  of  Science  and  Technology  (MOST).4 
Furthermore, VBARD staff stated in meetings and written communications that VBARD has no 
separate policy on the environment. To compensate for these policy deficiencies, ADB has 
found it beneficial in the past to develop loan-specific guidelines and procedures for borrowers 
of VBARD funds. The most relevant VBARD example is the ADB-financed Rural Credit Project 
where environmental guidelines were produced and applied to rural credit loan borrowers.5 The 
guidelines  state  that  (i)  subprojects  need  to  meet  Viet  Nam’s  environmental  laws  and 
regulations (footnote 4); (ii) loans cannot be used to purchase or use a specific list of banned 
pesticides; and (iii) subprojects cannot have any negative impact on erosion, deforestation, the 
local community, noise, dust, etc. A second example is the State Bank of Vietnam’s (SBV) 
Environmental Assessment of Rural Credit Loans in Viet Nam: Field Guidelines (January 2000). 
These guidelines are for the use of credit officers assessing the environmental and health risks 
posed by rural credit loans. The guidelines cover subprojects in land clearing, fertilizer use, 
pesticide  use,  livestock,  poultry,  artisanal  fishing,  aquaculture,  food  processing,  leather 
production, brick manufacturing, ceramics, and an appendix containing a one-page environment 
form for credit officers and borrowers to fill-out. However, it was found that VBARD credit 
officers seldom use the guidelines.  
 
7.  While  VBARD’s  policy  framework  for  environmental  protection  is  modest,  VBARD 
nevertheless operates under an internal set of environmental assessment procedures. For large 
projects that have significant environment impacts, VBARD requires the project owners to hire 
related  authority  agencies  to  evaluate  their  project’s  environment  impacts  and  submit 
environmental impacts assessment to VBARD for consideration. For medium-sized projects, 
VBARD’s credit officers assessed the environment impacts during the project appraisal process 
(e.g., waste treatment measures, environmental pollution, measures to minimize environmental 
impacts, and measures to improve environment impacts in accordance to recommendations of 
the related authority agencies). According to VBARD, the credit officers primarily use their 
practical work experience to conduct environmental appraisal duties. VBARD states it has not 
organized any training course specifically on environment issues for these credit officers, with 
the  exception  of  some  training  courses  organized  by  the  International  Credit  Project 
Management Unit of SBV under the Rural Credit Project. 
 
8.  The expected impacts of representative subprojects supported by the Project were also 
reviewed. The screening began by merging representative subprojects into three categories: 
(i) transport subprojects, (ii) food processing subprojects, and (iii) light industrial subprojects. 
Most projects funded under the loan are expected to fall into one of these three categories. The 
screening considered a wide range of situations and therefore a wide range of impacts for each 
subproject category. For example, the location of a food processing plant in the forested area of 
the central highlands may have a mitigable impact, but a food processing plant located in a rural 
industrial zone of the Mekong delta may have no ecological impacts. In these cases, the 
precautionary principle was applied by ascribing a mitigable evaluation to the potential impact of 
all food processing locations. The screening found all subproject activities for all categories to 
have either not significant or mitigable impacts. If the mitigation measures are achieved, it is

C.  Institutional Requirement and Environmental Monitoring Program 
 
9.  The loan has an environmental management plan with two parts: (i) mitigation measures 
to minimize potential negative impacts and/or maximize potential positive impacts, and (ii) a 
monitoring framework to assess the efficiency of mitigation measures. 
 
10.  Two mitigating actions are proposed for the policy reform loan. The first is promoting 
sustainable agricultural development as a research priority of the Ministry of Agriculture and 
Rural Development (MARD). This mitigation does not require new research institutes to be 
created—it  only  requires  MARD  to  assign  to  one  or  more  existing  institutes  the  specific 
responsibility of designing and implementing research activities on agricultural practices that 
use natural resources and systems, in a way that environmental quality can be maintained for 
current and future generations. MARD should weave the knowledge acquired through this 
research into numerous practical activities. For example,  MARD can ensure that research 
grants are evaluated in part by sustainability criteria and/or provide 2-3 grants per year that 
focus  specifically  on  sustainable  agriculture.  This  can  be  achieved  by  adding  “sustainable 
questions” to the application process. For example, research applications could ask: “how will 
the  knowledge  acquired  from  this  research  protect  Viet  Nam’s  natural  environment?”  (the 
answer might be “to reduce deforestation rates”); or “how will the knowledge acquired from this 
research maintain or improve the quality of arable land in Viet Nam for future generations?” (the 
answer  might  be  “to  reduce  salinity  intrusion  for  arable  land  in  Mekong  delta,  therefore 
maintaining  total  hectares  of  arable  land”).  MARD  can  also  ensure  that  on-farm  research 
activities test new ideas and approaches for sustainable agriculture proposed by research 
institutes,  and  ensure  that  the  human  resource  development  plan  specifically  address 
sustainable agriculture as a development goal. 
 
11.  The second proposed mitigating action for the program loan is ensuring that extension 
services provide adequate knowledge relating to sustainable agriculture. To implement this 
measure, MARD should ensure that (i) the joint extension plan specifically states that staff will 
receive  training  on  practical  tools  and  approaches  for  agricultural  sustainability  and 
environmental protection; (ii) the terms of reference for contracted extension service providers 
should  include  a  requirement  to  disseminate  information  on  environmental  protection  and 
agricultural sustainability; and (iii) MARD could consider incorporating environmental risks (e.g., 
risks of biodiversity loss, increased air/water pollution, and soil contamination/erosion) into the 
risk analysis component of its proposed market information system. 
 
12.  One mitigation measure proposed for the project loan: to ensure that subprojects are 
designed  and  implemented  in  a  manner  that  promotes  sustainability  and  environmental 
protection. Actions to implement this mitigation measure follow: (i) VBARD will develop and 
submit to ADB an environmental and social management system (policy, procedure, resources) 
for its operations;6 (ii) if additional capacity is required to implement the system, VBARD should 
design  and  submit  a  capacity  development  plan  to  ADB;  and  (iii)  VBARD  will  submit  an 
environmental performance report on its environmental and social management system. 
                                                 
6 This system should be practical  and therefore  build  on existing  procedures that support sustainability and 
environmental protection (e.g., adopt relevant sections of (i) State Bank of Vietnam’s Environmental Assessment of 
Rural Credit Loans in Viet Nam: Field Guidelines (January 2000); and (ii) VBARD’s No. 1135 (July 08/97); 
Environmental Advice for loan applicants of the ADB Rural Credit Loan (pp. 52-56). In addition to existing policies 
and procedures, VBARD should consider the potential environmental impacts and mitigation measures presented.

13.  The implementation and effectiveness of mitigation measures described above need to 
be monitored in a systematic and transparent way. The monitoring programs should include 
clear  monitoring  objectives,  indicators  to  monitor,  monitoring  locations,  and  frequency  of 
monitoring. The results should be included in the loan’s regular reporting. 
 
D.  Findings and Recommendations 
 
14.  The loan supports many policy reforms and activities that have the potential to promote 
social and environmental sustainability as it relates to agricultural development in Viet Nam.7 
Making  sustainability  an  explicit  part  of  the  long-term  goal  will  clarify  the  purpose  for 
incorporating the below recommendations in the Program. 
 
15.  The program loan should have a net positive effect on the environment. However, there 
are many policy reforms with unknown impact. There is ample opportunity to increase the 
positive environmental impact of this loan by transforming unknown impacts into significant 
positive  impacts.  Adherence  to  the  following  recommendations  can  achieve  that.  The 
combination of letters and numbers refers to items in the policy matrix (Appendix 3). 
(i)  A1.1, A1.6, and A1.12: Restructuring of research institutes should result in at 
least one institute having sustainable agriculture as a primary research priority. 
The results of this research will be MARD’s knowledge base on environmental 
and social impacts for new and existing agriculture activities for present and 
future generations. The knowledge base can be communicated to other institutes 
as a set of guidelines, sustainability indicators, etc. Research results can then 
become information inputs into performance-based evaluation, on-farm research, 
and development of competitive grants (A1.3, A1.8). 
(ii)  A1.1: Conduct on-farm research on issues relating to sustainable agriculture. 
These issues can be selected and coordinated with activities of the institute(s) 
conducting sustainable agriculture research. 
(iii)  A.1.3  and  A1.8:  Ensure  research  grants  are  evaluated  in  part  by  a  set  of 
sustainability  criteria.  These  criteria  should  be  based  on  findings  of  the 
sustainable agriculture research program and the priorities of MARD and MOST 
(A1.1). 
(iv)  A1.5, A1.11, and A1.15: Ensure the MARD policy on proportional increases to 
research budgets explicitly states “research on sustainable agriculture.” 
(v)  A1.8:  Of  10  annual  research  grants,  2-3  grants  should  be  earmarked  for 
research on environmental protection or environmental sustainability. 
(vi)  A1.9. The human resource development plan should include specific objectives 
and activities relating to developing skills in sustainable agriculture. 
(vii)  A2.1: Operational guidelines for provincial extension advisory councils need to 
include  stakeholders  that  typically  have  an  interest  in  social  equity  and 
environmental  protection  (e.g.,  Departments  of  Science  and  Technology, 
women’s unions, and nongovernment organizations).

that environmental quality can be maintained for current and future generations.

(viii)  A2.2:  Some  extension  service  providers  should  disseminate  information  on 
environmental protection and agricultural sustainability. 
(ix)  A2.5: The extension plan should be designed to ensure that extension staff 
receive training on practical tools and approaches for agricultural sustainability 
and environmental protection. Relevant results from research institutes (A1.1) 
should be woven into the plan. 
(x)  A2.8: Ensure subject matter specialists listed in the regulation or circular include 
those with expertise in environmental sustainability and protection. 
(xi)  B1.1, B1.5, and B1.7: Plan for agricultural market information system should 
include information on environmental risks. These risks should be based on 
experiences of sustainable agriculture research institutes, on-farm research, and 
a priori knowledge. 
16.  The project loan has the potential to create a significant positive impact by increasing 
resource efficiency, reducing poverty, and promoting social equity while concurrently promoting 
environmental sustainability. However, to realize this potential, it is recommended that VBARD 
and ADB produce a set of specific lending and appraisal guidelines similar to those developed 
for the Rural Credit Project. These guidelines should be designed through cooperative dialogue 
with VBARD, field visits to potential project sites, and review of potential impacts and mitigation 
measures identified. A competent authority should monitor the progress of implementing the 
mitigating  and  monitoring  measures  as  part  of  the  regular  monitoring  program.  If  the 
recommendations are implemented successfully, the overall loan will have a greater net positive 
environmental benefit than the without-loan scenario. 
E.  Conclusions 
17.  Viet Nam’s agricultural system provides national food security, generation of surplus for 
industrialization,  and  competitiveness  of  the  economy  in  world  markets.  With  further 
intensification of the farming systems being required to meet future food and fiber needs, natural 
resources will be further stressed and sustainability issues will become more critical. In light of 
these demands, ADB is proposing an Agriculture Sector Development Program (ASDP). The 
Program  will  (i)  focus  on  a  series  of  policy  reforms  to  streamline  the  management  and 
competitiveness of agricultural research institutes, increase extension activities to rural farmers, 
and increase local participation in planning and decision making; and (ii) support VBARD in 
providing loans for value-added and non-primary production activities (e.g., transport, food 
processing, and light industry) to small- and medium-sized enterprises. 
18.  The environmental screening of the program loan yielded a mix of significant positive 
impacts,  unknown  impacts,  or  no  impacts.  Recommendations  to  maximize  the  positive 
environmental benefits of the policy loan are proposed in the initial environmental examination 
(IEE). The screening did not reveal any significant negative environmental impacts due to the 
proposed policy reforms. 
19.  The environmental screening of the project loan found a mix of no impacts, mitigable 
impacts,  or  insignificant  impacts.  Recommendations  to  mitigate  the  negative  impacts  are 
proposed in the IEE. If these mitigation measures are implemented, the loan has the potential to 
create a significant positive impact by increasing resource efficiency, reducing poverty, and 
promoting social equity while concurrently promoting environmental sustainability.

20.  Taking to account the entire loan package, the environmental impact screening identified 
no significant negative environmental impacts that cannot be mitigated. Indeed, ASDP will 
provide greater net positive impacts than the without-loan alternative. None of the policy reforms 
or representative projects are in category A. No further studies are required to complement the 
IEE.  Recommendations  to  maximize  the  positive  impacts  of  ASDP  and  monitor  the 
effectiveness of the mitigation measures are provided in the summary IEE.
